questiontext.text:
Hanim made a mistake when she calculated the value of her closing inventory. As a result, the inventory is undervalued.
How is her profit for the year and net assets at the end of the year affected by this error?

generalfeedback.text: Closing inventory is a credit in the statement of profit or loss so when it is undervalued it results in an understatement of profit. Closing inventory is also an asset in the statement of financial position, so undervaluing it also understates net assets.

answer.text: Profit for the year: Overstated, Net assets: Understated
Profit for the year: Overstated, Net assets: Overstated
Profit for the year: Understated, Net assets: Understated
Profit for the year: Understated, Net assets: Overstated

questiontext.text:
Ferhad runs a clothes shop selling replica football kits and valued all his inventory at 31 March 20X8 at its cost of $15,550.
Inventory includes 50 of last season's football kits which originally cost $30 and were on sale during the year for $50 each. However, now that new kits are out for the coming season, Ferhad knows he will have to reduce the old kits to half price in order to sell them.
Calculate the correct value for inventory at 31 March 20X8.

Answer: {1:NUMERICAL:=15300:0}

generalfeedback.text:
The kits from last season should be stated at the lower of the cost ($30) and the net realizable value (NRV).
NRV = Selling price - Cost to sell = ($50 / 2) - $0 = $25.
The lower of cost ($30) and NRV ($25) is $25.
The inventory value is calculated as:
$15,550 (Original Cost) – ($30 × 50) (Cost of 50 kits) + ($25 × 50) (NRV of 50 kits) = $15,550 – $1,500 + $1,250 = $15,300.

questiontext.text:
The following records were kept for an inventory item in September.

September 1 100 units in inventory at $10 each
September 5 50 units bought at $10 each
September 12 60 units sold
September 20 20 units bought at $8 each
September 29 80 units sold

Using the FIFO method, what would be the value of inventory at 30 September?

generalfeedback.text:
Total units available = 100 + 50 + 20 = 170 units.
Total units sold = 60 + 80 = 140 units.
Closing inventory = 170 – 140 = 30 units.

Using FIFO, the 140 units sold are matched to the earliest costs:
(1) 100 units @ $10 (Sept 1 batch)
(2) 40 units @ $10 (from Sept 5 batch: 50 available)

The remaining 30 units are from the latest purchases:
20 units @ $8(from Sep 20 purchase)$160
10 units @ $10(remaining from Sep 5 purchase: 50 – 40 sold)$100
Total30 units$260

questiontext.text:
Joe uses the continuous weighted average cost method of valuing inventories. During May 20X1, he recorded the following inventory details:
Opening balance 50 units valued at $4 each
4 May purchase of 50 units at $4.40 each
11 May issue of 80 units
19 May purchase of 60 units at $4.60 each
24 May issue of 50 units
What is the value of the inventory held at 31 May 20X1?

generalfeedback.text:
Date/ItemUnitsUnit cost ($)Total ($)Average ($)
Opening inventory504.00200
4 May purchase504.40220
Balance before issue1004204.20 (420/100)
11 May issue(80)4.20(336)
Balance after issue2084
19 May purchase604.60276
Balance before issue803604.50 (360/80)
24 May issue(50)4.50(225)
Closing inventory (31 May)30135

The value of the inventory held at 31 May 20X1 is $135.00.

questiontext.text:
Christopher has recently commenced trading and is unsure how to value his inventory. He needs to decide whether to use First-In First-Out (FIFO), or continuous weighted average.
One of the raw materials he uses in his business is oil. The price of oil has consistently risen and is expected to continue to rise.
Which of the following statements is correct?

generalfeedback.text: In a period of consistently rising prices, FIFO (First-In, First-Out) assumes the earliest (cheapest) inventory is sold first. This results in a lower Cost of Sales and, consequently, a higher reported profit compared to the continuous weighted average method, which uses a higher blended average cost.

answer.text: Christopher's profit will be the same regardless of the method of inventory valuation adopted
FIFO will lead to Christopher reporting a higher profit than if he uses continuous weighted average
Continuous weighted average will lead to a higher reported profit than if he uses FIFO
A more accurate profit will be reported if FIFO is used

questiontext.text: The entries required to correctly reflect inventory and cost of sales in the financial statements for the first year of trading are:

generalfeedback.text:
In the first year of trading, there is no opening inventory. The closing inventory is accounted for by debiting the asset account, Inventory (Statement of Financial Position - SOFP), and crediting the expense account (to reduce cost of sales), Trading A/C or Statement of Profit or Loss (as a deduction from Cost of Sales).
The correct entry is: Debit Inventory (SOFP) – closing inventory; Credit Trading A/C - closing inventory.

answer.text:
Debit Trading A/C - opening inventory
Credit Inventory (SOFP) – opening inventory
Debit Inventory (SOFP) – closing inventory
Credit Trading A/C - closing inventory

Debit Inventory (SOFP) – opening inventory
Credit Trading A/C – opening inventory
Debit Trading A/C - closing inventory
Credit Inventory (SOFP) – closing inventory

Debit Inventory (SOFP) – closing inventory
Credit Trading A/C - closing inventory

Debit Inventory (SOFP) – closing inventory
Credit Payables – closing inventory

questiontext.text:
An item of inventory could be sold for $100 after it has been modified at a cost of $21. The company incurs selling costs of 5% of selling price on each article sold. The cost is $45 per unit excluding carriage inwards of $2 and production overheads are $17 per unit.
Following the rules in IAS 2 at what valuation should this item be included in the inventory of the company?

generalfeedback.text:
Inventory must be valued at the lower of Cost and Net Realisable Value (NRV).
(1) Cost Calculation:
Cost = $45 (unit cost) + $2 (carriage inwards) + $17 (production overheads) = $64
(2) Net Realisable Value (NRV) calculation:
NRV = $100 (selling price) - $21 (modification cost) - (5% × $100) (selling costs) = $100 - $21 - $5 = $74
Lower of Cost ($64) and NRV ($74) is $64.

questiontext.text:
Danny Ltd had 200 units in inventory at 30 November 20X7 valued at $800. During December 20X7, it made the following purchases and sales.

02/12 Purchased 1,000 @ $5 each
05/12 Sold 700 @ $7.50 each
12/12 Purchased 800 @ $6.20 each
15/12 Purchased 300 @ $6.60 each
21/12 Sold 400 @ $8.00 each
28/12 Sold 500 @ $8.20 each

What is the value of closing inventory using FIFO?

generalfeedback.text:
Total Units Available = 200 (Opening) + 1,000 (02/12) + 800 (12/12) + 300 (15/12) = 2,300 units.
Total Units Sold = 700 + 400 + 500 = 1,600 units.
Closing Inventory Units = 2,300 - 1,600 = 700 units.

Using FIFO (First-In, First-Out), the closing inventory is valued at the cost of the most recent purchases:
300 units @ $6.60 (15/12 purchase)$1,980
400 units @ $6.20 (Remaining from 12/12 purchase)$2,480
Total Value$4,460

questiontext.text:
Flint Ltd sells one line of inventory. At the year-end it has 200 units in inventory which originally cost $10 per unit and had incurred delivery costs of $120 in total. They expect these goods to sell for $13 per unit. Flint Ltd incurs selling costs amounting to 10% of the selling price on all its sales.
In the statement of financial position these items should be valued at:

generalfeedback.text:
Inventory must be valued at the lower of Cost and Net Realisable Value (NRV).
(1) Total Cost Calculation:
200 units @ $10$2,000
Delivery cost (Carriage inwards)$120
Total Cost$2,120

Cost per unit = $2,120 / 200 = $10.60.
(2) Net Realisable Value (NRV) calculation per unit:
Selling Price per unit = $13
Selling costs per unit = 10% of $13 = $1.30
NRV per unit = $13 - $1.30 = $11.70.
Total NRV = 200 units × $11.70 = $2,340.
Lower of Cost ($2,120) and NRV ($2,340) is $2,120. The inventory is valued at cost.

questiontext.text:
Luna makes the following purchases in the year:
DateUnits$/unitTotal ($)
21.01.X910012.001,200
30.04.X930012.503,750
31.07.X94012.80512
01.09.X96013.00780
11.11.X98013.501,080

At the year-end 200 units are in inventory but 8 are damaged and are only worth $10 per unit. These are identified as having been part of the 11.11.X9 delivery. Luna operates a FIFO system for valuing inventory.
The figure for inventory at 31.12.X9 is:

generalfeedback.text:
Total Inventory = 200 units.
(1) Valuation of Damaged Units (8 units):
Cost per unit (from 11.11.X9 delivery) = $13.50.
Net Realisable Value (NRV) per unit = $10.00.
Value (Lower of Cost and NRV) = $10.00 per unit.
Damaged Inventory Value = 8 units × $10.00 = $80.

(2) Valuation of Undamaged Units (200 – 8 = 192 units):
Using FIFO, these are valued from the latest purchases at cost:
SourceUnitsRate ($)Total ($)
11.11.X9 (80 - 8 damaged)72@ $13.50972
01.09.X960@ $13.00780
31.07.X940@ $12.80512
30.04.X9 (192 - 72 - 60 - 40)20@ $12.50250
Total Undamaged1922,514

(3) Total Inventory Value:
Total Inventory Value = $80 (Damaged) + $2,514 (Undamaged) = $2,594.

questiontext.text:
Fariz recently commenced trading. The materials Fariz uses in the business are subject to regular price rises. Fariz is unsure how to value inventory and is trying to decide whether to use 'first in, first out' (FIFO), or continuous weighted average.
Which of the following statements is correct?

generalfeedback.text: In a period of regular price rises, FIFO assumes the earliest (cheapest) purchases are sold first, resulting in a lower Cost of Sales and therefore a higher reported profit.

answer.text: Fariz's profit will be unaffected by the method of inventory valuation
FIFO will lead to the higher reported profit
Continuous weighted average will lead to the higher reported profit
The profit will be more accurate if FIFO is used

questiontext.text:
Yana are preparing the final accounts for a business. The cost of the items in closing inventory is $41,875. This includes some items which cost $1,960 and which were damaged in transit. Yana estimated that it will cost $360 to repair the items, and that the items could then be sold for $1,200.
What was the correct inventory valuation for inclusion in the final accounts?

Answer: {1:NUMERICAL:=40755:0}

generalfeedback.text:
The damaged items must be valued at the lower of cost or Net Realisable Value (NRV).
Description$
Cost of damaged items1,960
Expected sale value1,200
Less cost of repairs(360)
Net realisable value (NRV)840

The lower of cost ($1,960) and NRV ($840) is $840.
Write down required on damaged items: $1,960 (Cost) - $840 (NRV) = $1,120.
Correct Inventory Valuation = Total Cost - Write Down
Correct Inventory Valuation = $41,875 - $1,120 = $40,755.

questiontext.text:
Susanti uses the first in, first out method of inventory valuation. At 1 May 20X8 Susanti had 60 units in inventory at a total value of $1,320. The movements in inventory in May 20X8 were as follows:
DateMovementUnitsRate ($)
14 MayReceipts (Purchase)12022.20
26 MayReceipts (Purchase)15022.30
18 MaySales90
28 MaySales80

What was the value of Susanti's inventory at 31 May 20X8?

Answer: {1:NUMERICAL:=3567:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Opening inventory unit cost: $1,320 / 60 units = $22.00.
Total Units Available = 60 (Opening) + 120 (14 May) + 150 (26 May) = 330 units.
Total Units Sold = 90 + 80 = 170 units.
Closing Inventory Units = 330 - 170 = 160 units.

Using FIFO, the 160 units in closing inventory are valued at the cost of the most recent purchases (last-in):
150 units @ $22.30(26 May delivery)$3,345
10 units @ $22.20(Remaining from 14 May delivery)$222
Total Value$3,567

questiontext.text:
Manesh uses the periodic weighted average method of inventory valuation. At 1 August 20X6 Manesh had 60 units in inventory at a total value of $1,320. The inventory movements during August 20X6 were as follows:
DateMovementUnitsRate ($)
14 AugReceipts12022.50
26 AugReceipts15023.36
18 AugSales90
28 AugSales80

What was the value of Manesh's inventory at 31 August 20X6?

Answer: {1:NUMERICAL:=3648:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Under the periodic weighted average method, the average cost is calculated for all units available for sale during the period.
(1) Total Cost and Units Available:
ItemUnitsUnit cost ($)Total cost ($)
Opening inventory6022.00 (1,320/60)1,320.00
14 Aug Purchase12022.502,700.00
26 Aug Purchase15023.363,504.00
Total Available3307,524.00

Weighted Average Cost per unit = $7,524.00 / 330 units = $22.80.
(2) Closing Inventory Units:
Closing Inventory Units = 330 (Available) - 90 (18 Aug Sale) - 80 (28 Aug Sale) = 160 units.
(3) Closing Inventory Value:
Closing Inventory Value = 160 units × $22.80 = $3,648.00.

questiontext.text:
Kunta Kinte the continuous weighted average cost method of inventory valuation. At 1 February 20X4 Kunta Kinte had 60 units in inventory at a total value of $1,320. The inventory movements during February 20X4 were as follows:
Receipts14 Feb180 units @ $23 per unit
Sales18 Feb90 units @ $30 per unit

What was the value of Kunta Kinte's inventory at 28 February 20X4?

generalfeedback.text:
Under the continuous weighted average method, the average cost is recalculated after each purchase.
ItemUnitsUnit cost ($)Total cost ($)
Opening inventory (1 Feb)6022.001,320.00
14 Feb Purchase18023.004,140.00
Balance before sale24022.75 (5,460/240)5,460.00
18 Feb Sale (Cost of Sales)(90)22.75(2,047.50)
Closing Inventory (28 Feb)15022.753,412.50

The value of Kunta Kinte's inventory at 28 February 20X4 is $3,412.50.

questiontext.text:
Andrew uses the continuous weighted average cost method of inventory valuation. At 1 April 20X5 Andrew had 120 units in inventory at a unit cost of $22.00. The inventory movements during April 20X5 were as follows:
MovementDateUnitsRate ($)
Receipts15 Apr36023.00 (per unit)
Sales25 Apr30032.00 (per unit - selling price)

What was Andrew's cost of sales for the month of April 20X5?

Answer: {1:NUMERICAL:=6825:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Under the continuous weighted average cost method, the cost of sales is calculated using the weighted average cost just before the sale.
(1) Opening Inventory Value: 120 units × $22.00 = $2,640.00
(2) 15 Apr Purchase Value: 360 units × $23.00 = $8,280.00
(3) Weighted Average Cost (before 25 Apr sale):
Total Units: 120 + 360 = 480 units
Total Cost: $2,640.00 + $8,280.00 = $10,920.00
Weighted Average Cost per unit = $10,920.00 / 480 units = $22.75
(4) Cost of Sales (25 Apr sale):
Units Sold: 300 units
Cost of Sales = 300 units × $22.75 = $6,825.00.
